'''Aeronomy''' is the meteorological science of the upper region of the Earth's or other planetary [[atmosphere|atmospheres]], which relates to the atmospheric motions, its chemical composition and properties, and the reaction to it from the environment from space.<ref>{{cite book|first=Guy|last= Brasseur|pages=xi|title=''Aeronomy of the Middle Atmosphere : Chemistry and Physics of the Stratosphere and Mesosphere''||publisher=Springer |year=1984|ISBN=978-94-009-6403-7}}</ref> The term ''aeronomy'' was introduced<ref>{{cite book| first=Andrew F.|last= Nagy|pages=1–2 |title=''Comparative Aeronomy''|author2=Balogh, André|author3= Thomas E. Cravens|author4=Mendillo, Michael|author5=Mueller-Woodarg, Ingo|publisher=Springer |year=2008|ISBN=978-0-387-87824-9}}</ref> by [[Sydney Chapman (mathematician)|Sydney Chapman]] in a [[Letter to the Editor]] of ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' entitled ''Some Thoughts on Nomenclature'' in 1946.<ref>Sydney Chapman, "Some Thoughts on Nomenclature," ''Nature'' '''157''', (1946): 405. Available on-line at: [http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v157/n3987/abs/157405b0.html ''Nature''].</ref> Studies within the subject also investigate the causes of [[dissociation (chemistry)|dissociation]] or [[ionization]] processes.<ref>{{cite book|last=Chapman|first=Sydney|title=The Thermosphere - the Earth's Outermost Atmosphere|series= Physics of the Upper Atmosphere |year=1960|publisher=[[Academic Press]]|isbn=978-0-12-582050-9|pages=4}}</ref>
Today the term also includes the science of the corresponding regions of the atmospheres of other planets. Aeronomy is a branch of [[atmospheric physics]]. Research in aeronomy requires access to balloons, satellites, and [[sounding rockets]] which provide valuable data about this region of the atmosphere. [[Atmospheric tide]]s dominate the dynamics of the [[mesosphere]] and lower [[thermosphere]], essential to understanding the atmosphere as a whole. Other phenomena studied are [[upper-atmospheric lightning]] discharges, such as [[Sprite (lightning)|red sprites]], sprite halos or blue jets.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}}
==Atmospheric tides== {{Main|Atmospheric tide}} [[Atmospheric tide]]s are global-scale periodic oscillations of the [[atmosphere]]. In many ways they are analogous to ocean [[tides]]. Atmospheric tides form an important mechanism for transporting energy input into the lower atmosphere from the upper atmosphere, while dominating the dynamics of the mesosphere and lower thermosphere. Therefore, learning about atmospheric tides is essential in understanding the atmosphere as a whole. Modeling and observations of atmospheric tides are needed in order to monitor and predict changes in the Earth's atmosphere.<ref name=VollandAT>Volland, H., "Atmospheric Tidal and Planetary Waves", Kluwer Publ., Dordrecht, 1988</ref>
==Upper-atmospheric lightning== [[File:Upperatmoslight1.jpg|300px|thumb|right|Representation of upper-atmospheric lightning and electrical-discharge phenomena]] {{Main|Upper-atmospheric lightning|Sprites (lightning)}} [[Upper-atmospheric lightning]] or upper-atmospheric discharge are terms sometimes used by researchers to refer to a family of electrical-breakdown phenomena that occur well above the altitudes of normal [[lightning]]. The preferred current usage is '''[[transient luminous event]]s''' ('''TLEs''') to refer to the various types of electrical-discharge phenomena induced in the upper atmosphere by tropospheric lightning. TLEs includes red sprites, sprite halos, blue jets, and elves.<ref>Earle R. Williams (November 2001) "Sprites, elves, and glow discharge tubes," ''Physics Today'', '''54''' (11) : 41-47. Available on-line at: [http://physicstoday.org/journals/doc/PHTOAD-ft/vol_54/iss_11/41_1.shtml?bypassSSO=1 ''Physics Today''] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120527085255/http://physicstoday.org/journals/doc/PHTOAD-ft/vol_54/iss_11/41_1.shtml?bypassSSO=1 |date=2012-05-27 }}.</ref>
==See also==
*[[Meteorology]] *[[Atmospheric chemistry]] *[[Space physics]]

[[File:Association of Art Historians logo.jpg|thumb|The AAH logo.]]
The '''Association of Art Historians''' ('''AAH''') promotes the professional practice and public understanding of [[art history]].<ref name=aah>[http://www.aah.org.uk/page/2757 About AAH.] Association of Art Historians, 2015. Retrieved 5 February 2015.</ref> It was formed in 1974, is based in [[London]], [[England]], and is a [[registered charity]] (No. 1154066).<ref name="cc" />
==Membership== Individual membership is open to anyone with a professional commitment to and interest in art history and visual culture. Institutional membership is also available.<ref name="aah" />
Members can get involved in the following interest groups:
*Freelance and independents *Higher and further education *Schools *Students *Museums & exhibitions.
==Governance and financial== The Association is governed by a Board of Trustees. For the year ended 31 December 2010, the AAH had a gross income of £396,818 and expenditure of £359,507 according to accounts filed with the [[Charity Commission]].<ref name="cc">[http://www.charity-commission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithoutPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=282579&SubsidiaryNumber=0 Association of Art Historians], [[Charity Commission for England and Wales|The Charity Commission]], UK, 2011. Retrieved 21 July 2011.</ref>
==Publications== There is a quarterly newsletter, the ''Bulletin'', and a scholarly journal ''[[Art History (journal)|Art History]]'' published five times a year in association with [[Wiley-Blackwell]], which is peer-reviewed.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://art-history.concordia.ca/rvacanada/associations.html | title=Art History Associations | publisher=[[Concordia University]] | location=Canada | accessdate=4 November 2012 }}</ref>
==Events== Regular events take place, often organised by volunteers from the various member interest groups, together with an annual conference.
==Affiliations== The AAH is affiliated with the US [[College Art Association]] (CAA) and supports the [[Comité International d'Histoire de l'Art]] (CIHA).<ref name="aah" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.aah.org.uk AAH official website] *[http://www.aah.org.uk/programmes-archive AAH Annual Conference Programme Archive] (PDF) *[http://www.charity-commission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithoutPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=282579&SubsidiaryNumber=0 Charity Commission page about the AAH including historic financial information]

{{Infobox Museum |name = Aznavour Center |native_name = Ազնավուրի կենտրոն |native_name_lang = Armenian |image = Museum of Aznavur in Armenia.jpg |imagesize = 300px |caption = |alt = |map_type = |map_caption = |map_alt = |latitude = |longitude = |established = 2011 |dissolved = |location = [[Yerevan]], [[Armenia]] |type = Biographical museum and cultural centre |collection = |visitors = |director = Christina Sargsyan |president = |curator = |publictransit = |network = |website = }} '''Aznavour Center''',<ref>[https://aznavourfoundation.org/en/aznavourcenter/ Aznavour Center]</ref> also known as '''Maison Charles Aznavour''', is a music centre in [[Yerevan]], [[Armenia]], housing a technological and interactive museum about the life of [[Charles Aznavour]], and a cultural and educational center for youth. It was opened in 2011 by the ''Aznaviur Foundation'' to become the ''Residence of Charles Aznavour'' in Armenia. It occupies a five-story building near the top of the [[Yerevan Cascade]] and includes an open-air concert hall, as well as Aznavour's apartment and the museum itself. The current director of the Aznavour Center and Foundation is Christina Sargsyan.<ref>[https://www.tert.am/en/news/2017/06/01/Kristina-sarkisyan/2389821 Aznavour Museum to host great singer to tell about his life – foundation director]</ref>
==Overview== French-Armenian singer [[Charles Aznavour]] cut the ribbon of the centre at the opening ceremony on October 7, 2011.<ref>[http://www.azatutyun.am/a/24352450.html Երեւանում բացվեց Շառլ Ազնավուրի թանգարանը]</ref> It was attended by French President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] and Armenian President [[Serzh Sargsyan]].<ref>[http://www.armeniadiaspora.com/news/5819-sarkozy-opens-charles-aznavour-museum-in-yerevan.html Sarkozy Opens Charles Aznavour Museum in Yerevan] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111112214307/http://www.armeniadiaspora.com/news/5819-sarkozy-opens-charles-aznavour-museum-in-yerevan.html |date=November 12, 2011 }}</ref>
The exhibition includes Aznavour's [[Gramophone record|discs]], [[album]]s, books, music awards, [[poster]]s and [[photography|photographs]].
The project was launched in 2007, funded by the Armenian government. Aznavour’s foundation decorated the interior of the museum.<ref>[http://rt.com/art-and-culture/news/aznavour-erevan-317/ Museum of Charles Aznavour opens in Armenia] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418011340/http://rt.com/art-and-culture/news/aznavour-erevan-317/ |date=April 18, 2012 }}</ref>
On June 1, 2017 President Sargsyan attended key handover ceremony of Maison Charles Aznavour.<ref>[https://armenpress.am/eng/news/893192/president-sargsyan-attends-key-handover-ceremony-of-charles-aznavour-house-museum.html President Sargsyan attends key handover ceremony of Charles Aznavour house-museum, Armenpress, 2017]</ref><ref>[https://www.azatutyun.am/a/28523091.html «Ազնավուր» հիմնադրամը շարունակելու է աշխարհահռչակ երգչի բարեգործական գործունեությունը]</ref>
== See also == * [[List of music museums]]

'''Bioconversion''', also known as ''biotransformation'', is the conversion of organic materials, such as plant or animal waste, into usable products or [[energy source]]s by biological processes or agents, such as certain microorganisms. One example is the industrial production of [[cortisone]], which one step is the bioconversion of [[progesterone]] to 11-alpha-Hydroxyprogesterone by ''[[Rhizopus nigricans]].'' Another example is the [[Bioconversion of Glycerol to 1,3-Propanediol|bioconversion of glycerol to 1,3-propanediol]], which is part of scientific research for many decades.
Another example of bioconversion is the [[Conversion (chemistry)|conversion]] of [[organic material]]s, such as plant or animal waste, into usable products or [[energy source]]s by biological processes or agents, such as certain [[microorganism]]s, some [[detritivore]]s or [[enzyme]]s.
In the USA, the Bioconversion Science and Technology group performs multidisciplinary R&D for the [[United_States_Department_of_Energy|Department of Energy]]'s (DOE) relevant applications of bioprocessing, especially with biomass. Bioprocessing combines the disciplines of chemical engineering, microbiology and biochemistry. The Group 's primary role is investigation of the use of microorganism, microbial consortia and microbial enzymes in bioenergy research. New [[cellulosic ethanol]] conversion processes have enabled the variety and volume of [[feedstock]] that can be bioconverted to expand rapidly. Feedstock now includes materials derived from plant or animal waste such as paper, auto-fluff, tires, fabric, construction materials, [[municipal solid waste]] (MSW), [[sludge]], [[sewage]], etc.
==Three different processes for bioconversion== 1 -''' Enzymatic hydrolysis''' - a single source of feedstock, switchgrass for example, is mixed with strong enzymes which convert a portion of cellulosic material into sugars which can then be fermented into ethanol. [[Genencor]] and [[Novozymes]] are two companies that have received United States government Department of Energy funding for research into reducing the cost of cellulase, a key enzyme in the production cellulosic ethanol by this process.
2 - '''Synthesis gas fermentation''' - a blend of feedstock, not exceeding 30% water, is [[gasified]] in a closed environment into a [[syngas]] containing mostly carbon monoxide and hydrogen. The cooled syngas is then converted into usable products through exposure to bacteria or other catalysts. BRI Energy, LLC<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brienergy.com/|title=Clean Technology for Renewable Energy|website=www.brienergy.com}}</ref> is a company whose pilot plant in Fayetteville, Arkansas is currently using synthesis gas fermentation to convert a variety of waste into ethanol. After gasification, anaerobic bacteria (''[[Clostridium ljungdahlii]]'') are used to convert the syngas ([[carbon monoxide|CO]], [[carbon dioxide|CO<sub>2</sub>]], and [[hydrogen|H<sub>2</sub>]]) into ethanol. The heat generated by gasification is also used to co-generate excess electricity.
3 - '''C.O.R.S.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Diener | first=Stefan | last2=Zurbrügg | first2=Christian | last3=Tockner | first3=Klement | title=Conversion of organic material by black soldier fly larvae: establishing optimal feeding rates | journal=Waste Management & Research | publisher=SAGE Publications | volume=27 | issue=6 | date=2009-06-05 | issn=0734-242X | doi=10.1177/0734242x09103838 | pages=603–610 | ref=harv}}</ref> and Grub Composting''' are sustainable technologies<ref>{{cite journal | last=Craig Sheppard | first=D. | last2=Larry Newton | first2=G. | last3=Thompson | first3=Sidney A. | last4=Savage | first4=Stan | title=A value added manure management system using the black soldier fly | journal=Bioresource Technology | publisher=Elsevier BV | volume=50 | issue=3 | year=1994 | issn=0960-8524 | doi=10.1016/0960-8524(94)90102-3 | pages=275–279 | ref=harv}}</ref> that employ organisms that feed on organic matter to reduce and convert organic waste in to high quality feedstuff and oil rich material for the biodiesel industry.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Li | first=Qing | last2=Zheng | first2=Longyu | last3=Cai | first3=Hao | last4=Garza | first4=E. | last5=Yu | first5=Ziniu | last6=Zhou | first6=Shengde | title=From organic waste to biodiesel: Black soldier fly, Hermetia illucens, makes it feasible | journal=Fuel | publisher=Elsevier BV | volume=90 | issue=4 | year=2011 | issn=0016-2361 | doi=10.1016/j.fuel.2010.11.016 | pages=1545–1548 | ref=harv}}</ref> Organizations pioneering this novel approach to [[waste management]] are [[EAWAG]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eawag.ch/forschung/sandec/gruppen/swm/projects/cors/index_EN|title=Abteilung Siedlungshygiene und Wasser für Entwicklung - Eawag|website=www.eawag.ch}}</ref>, ESR International<ref>http://www.esrint.com/pages/bioconversion.html</ref>, Prota Culture<ref>http://www.thebiopod.com</ref> and BIOCONVERSION<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bioconversion.it/|title=Contatti|website=www.bioconversion.it}}</ref> that created the ''e''-CORS® system<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304054800/http://www.bioconversion.it/1/upload/bioconversion_presentazione_web.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=4 March 2012|publisher=}}</ref> to meet large scale organic waste management needs and environmental sustainability in both urban and livestock farming reality. This type of engineered system introduces a substantial innovation represented by the automatic modulation of the treatment, able to adapt conditions of the system to the biology of the scavenger used, improving their performances and the power of this technology.

{{Use Australian English|date=June 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} The '''Castan Centre for Human Rights Law''' is a research centre located within the [[Monash University Law Faculty]] in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[Australia]]. It was established in 2000 to meet the need for, and interest in, the study of [[human rights law]] globally, regionally and in Australia. It grew rapidly to become the largest research centre in the Monash Law School.<ref name="Castan Centre for Human Rights">[http://www.law.monash.edu.au/castancentre/index.html Castan Centre for Human Rights<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It is the preeminent human rights centre in the Asia-Pacific region,<ref>[http://www.law.monash.edu/humanwrites/castan-centre.html Monash Castan Centre for Human Rights Law<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902133153/http://law.monash.edu/humanwrites/castan-centre.html |date=2007-09-02 }}</ref> and is one of Australia's most respected human rights monitoring organisations.<ref>[http://www.nit.com.au/news/story.aspx?id=10743 NIT<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091023200309/http://www.nit.com.au/news/story.aspx?id=10743 |date=2009-10-23 }}</ref> Its function is to bring together the work of national and international human rights scholars, practitioners and advocates from a wide range of disciplines in order to promote and protect human rights.
The Centre is named after [[Ron Castan]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AM,|QC}} (1939-1999), a distinguished [[barrister]] who was a prominent advocate of [[human rights]].<ref name="Castan Centre for Human Rights"/><ref>[http://www.hcourt.gov.au/speeches/kirbyj/kirbyj_castan2.htm LAUNCH OF THE CASTAN CENTRE FOR HUMAN RIGHTS LAW MELBOURNE, TUESDAY, 31 OCTOBER 2000<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060820052133/http://www.hcourt.gov.au/speeches/kirbyj/kirbyj_castan2.htm |date=20 August 2006 }}</ref> His daughter, [[Melissa Castan]], is Deputy Director of the Centre.
==Activities== The Centre's main activities are research, teaching, public education (lectures, seminars, conferences, parliamentary submissions, internships and media presentations), applied research, advice work, policy work and consultancies.
===Teaching and research=== In teaching, it offers Australia's only [[Master of Laws]] in Human Rights. In collaboration with law firm [[Holding Redlich]], it runs the Holding Redlich Distinguished Visiting Fellowship Program, which attracts human rights experts from around the world to give public lectures on key human rights issues.<ref>[http://www.holdingredlich.com.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=13&Itemid=44 Holding Redlich - Law Firm Melbourne Sydney Brisbane - Holding Redlich Firm Profile<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Recent Fellows include Justice [[Richard Goldstone]] (2009), Justice [[Thomas Buergenthal]] (2009), [[Kirsty Sword Gusmão]] (2008) and Professor [[Peter H. Russell|Peter Russell]] (2006). Additionally, Monash students and staff and the general public enjoy regular lectures by prominent human rights academics and advocates hosted by the Centre, with recent guest speakers including prominent [[barrister]] [[Julian Burnside]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|QC}}, [[East Timor]] President Dr [[José Ramos-Horta]], the [[Dalai Lama]], former British first lady [[Cherie Booth]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|QC}}, Indigenous Australians [[Australian Senate|Senator]] [[Aden Ridgeway]] and [[Noel Pearson]], former [[Minister for Foreign Affairs]] [[Alexander Downer]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|MP}} and [[Prime Minister of Australia]] [[Kevin Rudd]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|MP}}.<ref>[http://www.law.monash.edu.au/castancentre/public-edu/public-lectures.html Public Events<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830063342/http://www.law.monash.edu.au/castancentre/public-edu/public-lectures.html |date=2007-08-30 }}</ref> The Centre administers numerous student [[internships]] enabling Monash undergraduate students to work at the [[United Nations Human Rights Council]], the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]] and the [[Khmer Rouge]] trials.<ref>[http://www.law.monash.edu.au/internships/index.html International Study and Internships<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080403194835/http://www.law.monash.edu.au/internships/index.html |date=2008-04-03 }}</ref>
Castan Centre staff undertake and publish extensive research in a wide range of areas related to human rights. To this end, it has received extensive funding from both government and non-government organisations, as well as some private industry sponsorship.<ref>[http://www.law.monash.edu/castancentre/projects/research.html Research<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705214222/http://law.monash.edu/castancentre/projects/research.html |date=2008-07-05 }}</ref> Some of the Centre's past projects have included an investigation into the role of the [[World Trade Organization]] in promoting human rights,<ref>[http://www.law.monash.edu/castancentre/projects/wto/wto-project.html Castan Centre for Human Rights Law<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705212528/http://law.monash.edu/castancentre/projects/wto/wto-project.html |date=2008-07-05 }}</ref> and the human rights responsibilities of [[multinational corporations]].<ref>[http://www.law.monash.edu/castancentre/projects/mchr/ Castan Centre for Human Rights Law<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725010830/http://law.monash.edu/castancentre/projects/mchr/ |date=2008-07-25 }}</ref>
===Consultancy and training=== In its advisory and consultancy capacity, it advises and produces research papers for a range of human rights-related organisations, such as the [[World Bank]], the [[World Organisation Against Torture]], the Indonesian Ministries of Justice and Finance, the Iraqi Ministry of Human Rights and the Australian [[Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (Australia)|Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade]].<ref>[http://www.law.monash.edu.au/castancentre/projects/advisory.html Castan Centre for Human Rights Law<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830063317/http://www.law.monash.edu.au/castancentre/projects/advisory.html |date=2007-08-30 }}</ref> Castan Centre staff have also been retained to conduct training and advice in some of the worlds human rights troublespots, such as [[Yangon]] in [[Burma]].<ref>[http://www.law.monash.edu.au/castancentre/projects/training.html Castan Centre for Human Rights Law<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719113452/http://www.law.monash.edu.au/castancentre/projects/training.html |date=2008-07-19 }}</ref>
==Management and governance== The Centre is guided and governed by an Advisory Board which consists of several notable legal practitioners and researchers.<ref>[http://www.law.monash.edu.au/castancentre/about/advisoryboard.html Advisory Board<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Current members of the Board include: * Professor [[Philip Alston]] - Professor of Law at [[New York University]] * Professor Virginia Dandan - Chairperson of the United Nations Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights * [[Patrick Dodson]] - Advocate for Indigenous Australians, founder of the Lingiari Foundation * The Hon. [[Elizabeth Evatt]] [[Companion of the Order of Australia|AC]] - Former Chief Judge of the [[Family Court of Australia]], President of the Australian Law Reform Commission, Chair of the [[United Nations]] [[Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women]] (CEDAW), Vice-Chair of the [[United Nations Human Rights Committee]], Judge of the [[World Bank]] Administrative Tribunal, Commissioner of the [[International Committee of Jurists]] * Professor [[Claudio Grossman]] - Dean of the [[Washington College of Law]] * Judge [[Felicity Hampel]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|SC}} - prominent human rights lawyer, Judge of the [[County Court of Victoria]] * Justice [[Michael Kirby (judge)|Michael Kirby]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AC,|CMG}} - former Justice of the [[High Court of Australia]] * Professor [[Christopher Weeramantry]] - Former Judge and Vice-President of the [[International Court of Justice]]
The current Director of the Castan Centre is human rights scholar Professor [[Sarah Joseph (Australian legal academic)|Sarah Joseph]].<ref>[http://www.law.monash.edu.au/castancentre/about/our-people.html Our People<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> She replaced Founding Director Professor David Kinley, who served until 2005.<ref>[http://www.law.usyd.edu.au/about/staff/DavidKinley/ Professor David Kinley - Sydney Law School - The University of Sydney<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316071612/http://www.law.usyd.edu.au/about/staff/DavidKinley/ |date=2008-03-16 }}</ref> Joseph is best known internationally for her work on the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] (ICCPR).<ref>[http://www.lawyersweekly.com.au/articles/Joseph-to-direct-Monash-human-rights-centre_z66363.htm Joseph to direct Monash human rights centre<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The Centre has 5 Deputy Directors. The Deputy Directors are academic staff members of the Monash University Law Faculty and are responsible (with the Director) for the management of the Castan Centre: * Dr Julie Debeljak * Ms Melissa Castan * Assistant Professor Paula Gerber (also President of [[Kaleidoscope Australia Human Rights Foundation]]) * Professor Susan Kneebone * Dr Adam McBeth
The Castan Centre also has a number of Associates: * Dr Heli Askola * Associate Professor Gideon Boas * Ms Azadeh Dastyari * Dr Patrick Emerton * Dr Stephen Gray * Ms Tania Penovic * Dr Joanna Kyriakakis * David Yarrow
The Castan Centre has three full-time staff members, the Centre Manager, Project Officer and Centre Administrator.
==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.law.monash.edu.au/castancentre Castan Centre webpage] * [http://www.law.monash.edu.au/ Monash Law Faculty webpage] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060820052133/http://www.hcourt.gov.au/speeches/kirbyj/kirbyj_castan2.htm Justice Kirby's Speech on the Launch of the Centre] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070313111556/http://www.lawyersweekly.com.au/articles/56/0c02c556.asp Dr Joseph replaces Dr Kinley as Director] * [http://www.abc.net.au/rn/lawreport/stories/2005/1302287.htm Dr Joseph talks about torture, ABC Radio National Feb 2005] {{Monash University}} [[Category:Monash University]] [[Category:Human rights organisations based in Australia]] [[Category:Legal research institutes]]

{{Infobox university | name = Concordia University Texas | image = Big austinchambermusic 126057.jpg | native_name = | image_name = | image_size = 200px | image_alt = | caption = | latin_name = | motto = "Developing Christian Leaders" | established = 1926 | closed = | type = [[Private school|Private]] | religious_affiliation= [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]] | endowment = [[United States dollar|US$]]13.3 millionhttp://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/austin-tx/concordia-austin-3557 | officer_in_charge = | chairman = | chancellor = | president = Dr. Don Christian | vice-president = | superintendent = | provost = | vice_chancellor = | rector = | principal = | dean = | director = | head_label = | head = | academic_staff = | administrative_staff = | students = 2565 | undergrad = 1531 | postgrad = 1034 | doctoral = | other = | city = [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] | state = [[Texas]] | province = | country = [[United States|USA]] | coor = {{coord|30|25|12|N|97|50|13|W|type:edu_region:US-TX|display=title,inline}} | campus = [[Suburb]]an, {{convert|380|acre|ha}} | former_names = | free_label = | free = | sports = | colors = Purple and gold {{color box|#4A1F78}} {{color box|#F2AE22}} | colours = | nickname = | mascot = Tornados | athletics = [[NCAA Division III]] – [[American Southwest Conference|ASC]] | affiliations = [[Concordia University System]]
[[National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities|NAICU]][http://www.naicu.edu/member_center/members.asp NAICU – Member Directory] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151109231238/http://www.naicu.edu/member_center/members.asp |date=November 9, 2015 }} | website = {{URL|http://www.concordia.edu/}} | logo = | footnotes = }} [[File:Concordia Univesity Texas Entrance.jpg|thumb|Main entrance]] '''Concordia University Texas''' is a [[Private university|private]], [[coeducational]] institution of [[liberal arts]] and [[sciences]] located in northwest [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Texas]]. The university offers [[undergraduate]], [[Graduate school|graduate]] and online degrees as well as an Adult Degree Program for part-time and returning students. Concordia University Texas is affiliated with the [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]] (LCMS) and is a member of the [[Concordia University System]], the nine-member association of LCMS colleges and universities. As a Lutheran university, Concordia's stated{{cite web|title=www.concordia.edu/sitefiles/w3/univservices/report/section%203.pdf|url=http://www.concordia.edu/sitefiles/w3/univservices/report/section%203.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527133142/http://www.concordia.edu/sitefiles/w3/Univservices/Report/Section%203.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-05-27|publisher=Concordia.edu}} mission is to develop [[Christian]] leaders. ==History== [[File:Kilianhall.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Historic Kilian Hall]] Concordia was founded in 1926 as '''Lutheran Concordia College of Texas''', a four-year [[high school]] that prepared young men for careers in ministry and teaching. The school opened with 26 students on its original site along East Avenue (now [[Interstate 35 in Texas|Interstate 35]]) on the then northern outskirts of Austin, Texas. In 1929, a two-story classroom building, later called the Music Building, and still later known as College Central, was built. Concordia was founded by members of [[Wends of Texas|Texas's Wendish]] immigrant community. The original main building, Kilian Hall, is named for the Wend [[John Kilian]], founder of the first Texas Lutheran church associated with the LCMS and leader of a large group of [[Sorbs|Wends]] (also called Sorbs) who settled in the [[Serbin, Texas|Serbin]] area. Today, between 10 and 15 percent of Concordia's faculty, staff and students are of Wendish heritage. Throughout the 1940s and 1950s many buildings were added to the campus, such as Hirschi Memorial Library in 1949 and Kramer Hall, the college's first fully air-conditioned classroom building, in 1950, but dedicated on February 25, 1951. Also in 1951, Concordia started using a two-year [[junior college]] curriculum. [[File:Concordiaoldfacultypic.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Old photograph of Concordia faculty in front of Kilian Hall]] Building developments on campus continued throughout the 1950s and 1960s. The campus built its chapel, named Birkmann Memorial Chapel, in 1952. Texas Hall, which housed dining services and faculty offices was dedicated in 1953. Studtmann Hall, an all-girl's dormitory opened in 1955. The first Beto Hall on the Concordia campus was built in 1969 and housed science labs. In the early 21st century, this building was converted into the school's mail services facility. In 1955 Concordia admitted women as students for the first time and the institution changed its name to '''Concordia Lutheran College''' in 1965. In 1969, the four-year high school program was disbanded and Concordia’s curriculum expanded to four years after receiving permission to award Bachelor of Arts degrees in 1980. Concordia joined the [[Concordia University System]] (CUS) in 1993. The CUS represents the ten colleges and universities run by the LCMS. In 1995, under the leadership of President Rev. Dr. David Zersen, the name of the institution was changed to '''Concordia University at Austin'''. The Accelerated Degree Program (ADP), with sites in Austin, [[Ft. Worth]], [[Houston]], and [[San Antonio]], within the College of Adult Education, was launched in 1995 to offer working adults the opportunity to earn a degree. Harms Hall, a dormitory, opened in January 2000 more than doubling campus resident capacity.The first Graduate program was developed during this period. In 2002, Dr. Thomas E. Cedel, a former fighter pilot and Colonel in the United States Air Force was named President of the university. In 2007, Concordia University at Austin changed its name to '''Concordia University Texas'''. In August 2008, Concordia University relocated its primary campus, moving onto more than {{convert|389|acre|ha}} in Northwest Austin. The city of Austin allowed the demolition of the former campus."[http://www.ci.austin.tx.us/agenda/2007/hlc_032607.htm Historic Landmark Commission Regular Meeting March 26, 2007 - 7:00 PM]." ''City of Austin''. Accessed September 28, 2008. A developer bought the space with plans to construct a mixed-use development; however, the developer filed for bankruptcy in 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.kvue.com/news/local/stories/042508kvueConcordia2-cb.9c7a4fb2.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-10-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080427155030/http://www.kvue.com/news/local/stories/042508kvueConcordia2-cb.9c7a4fb2.html |archivedate=2008-04-27 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Issue/column?oid=oid:449487|title=Developing Stories|author=|date=|website=austinchronicle.com}} The new campus was dedicated on October 26, 2008. ==New campus== In 2005, the Board of Regents approved the relocation of the Concordia University Texas campus. Since its founding the school had occupied a {{convert|23|acre|ha|adj=on}} campus near downtown Austin. The new campus is located in northwest Austin on {{convert|384|acre|ha}} of land. Construction began in the spring of 2007, and the new campus opened in September 2008. The site for Concordia's new campus is the former [[Schlumberger]] Austin Systems Center. The site, formerly an R&D facility, had six buildings connected by covered walkways and encircled by a nature trail. The six buildings, named by letter A-F, while extensively renovated, retained their basic design and features, including solid oak trim, large windows, sky lights and atria. Three new structures were built prior to occupation of the new Concordia campus: student housing, a fieldhouse and a front entry/guard house. In addition to the new structures, 600 additional parking spaces and new roads were built to handle the increased traffic on the campus. In 2014, Concordia broke ground on a state-of-the-art softball field that was completed in 2016. The campus includes a {{convert|250|acre|ha|adj=on}} [[nature preserve]] that has springs and wetlands, caves, dense trees and wildlife. A 10-A federal permit is required and only one other higher education institution carries one. The inclusion of the nature preserve allows Concordia to devote time to urban [[environmentalism]] in the Austin community. The Concordia University Nature Preserve is part of the Balcones Canyonlands Preserve, a system of preserves in western [[Travis County, Texas|Travis County]] that provides habitat for a number of rare and endangered plant and animal species such the [[Golden-cheeked warbler]] and [[Black-capped vireo]], two rare species of [[songbird]]s that breed in [[Central Texas]]. In 2013, Dr. Thomas E. Cedel, announced his retirement from Concordia University Texas. In 2014 Former Dean of the College of Business, Dr. Don Christian was named Chief Executive Officer. ==Student body== '''Student Body, Fall 2017''' *Total Enrollment: 2619 *Undergraduate: 1722 *Graduate: 897 ==Academics== Concordia University Texas has majors, minors, and programs of study within four colleges: Business & Communication, Nursing (accredited by the Texas Nursing Board and [[Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education|CCNE]]{{Cite web|url=https://absn.concordia.edu/about-concordia-texas/accreditations/|title=Concordia University Texas Accelerated Bachelor of Science in Nursing|last=|first=|date=|website=Accelerated BSN|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-20}}), Education, and Arts & Sciences. Concordia is accredited by the [[Southern Association of Colleges and Schools]] Commission on Colleges.{{cite web|url=http://www.sacscoc.org/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080318185250/http://www.sacscoc.org/ |archivedate=2008-03-18 |df= }} ==Campus life== Some of the many clubs and organizations that students participate in are: Concordia University Texas Collegiate [[DECA (organization)|DECA]], Concordia Outdoor Ministry, Service-Learning, Missions Club, Communication Club, Student Government & Leadership Association (SGLA), Concordia Youth Ministry Team (CYMT), [[Fellowship of Christian Athletes]], Helping Hands, History Club, Preseminarians of CTX, Society for Human Resource Management, Psychology Book Club, Kinesiology Club, Financial Management Association, Education Club, Directors of Christian Education Club, Biology Club, Behavioral Sciences Club, Association of Computing Machinery, Academic Advising Consultants, Model Organization of American States (MOAS), Moot Court, and the Spirit Squad. The school newspaper, ''The Mullet'', was first published in 2006, and in 2013 was renamed ''The Spin''. ''The Spin'' is published once a month during the semester. ==Athletics== The Concordia mascot is the '''Tornados''' and the school colors are purple and gold. Concordia's intercollegiate athletic teams participate in [[NCAA]] [[Division III (NCAA)|Division III]] competition within the [[American Southwest Conference]]. They do not award athletic scholarships per Division III rules. The athletic programs at Concordia are: baseball, softball, men's basketball, women's basketball, cross country, golf, [[Concordia Tornados men's soccer|men's soccer]], [[Concordia Tornados women's soccer|women's soccer]], track and field, volleyball, tennis and athletic training. In spring 2011, "Purple Out" events were started to encourage students, staff, and the community to support athletics. On designated "Purple Out" days, everyone is encouraged to wear purple and those attending a sporting event receive purple "Tornado Towels". In 2011-2012, Concordia Texas experienced its most successful year athletically. This was accomplished by winning ASC Championships in Women's Cross Country, Women's Basketball, and Men's Baseball (second consecutive championship). There were four athletic facilities on the old campus and one off-campus. On Campus: Fascholz-Keller Field (baseball), Bartholomew Park (softball), Pharr Tennis Center, Woltman Gymnasium. Off-campus: St. Francis School (soccer). Currently, men's and women's soccer play at St. Stephen's Episcopal School. Recently, the Concordia University soccer teams have been seen playing at Monroe Stadium at nearby Vandegrift High school. === Basketball === In the 2011-2012 season, the Concordia University Texas' women's basketball team won the American Southwest Conference. The Concordia Men's basketball team has been coached by Stanley Bonewitz Jr. since 2004. He is a former [[Texas Tech Red Raiders men's basketball|Texas Tech basketball]] standout. As a player, he was named Texas "Mr. Basketball" in 1995{{cite web |url=http://athletics.concordia.edu/athletics.cfm?page_ID=46 |title=Concordia University Coaching Staff - Basketball |work=CTX.edu |accessdate=2008-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070812204627/http://athletics.concordia.edu/athletics.cfm?page_ID=46 |archivedate=2007-08-12 |df= }} His father, Stanley Bonewitz Sr., recently retired as a state-championship winning coach at East Central High School in San Antonio. === Baseball === The Concordia Men's baseball team is coached by former major leaguer Tommy Boggs. Coach Boggs led the team to victory in 2011 as the ASC Conference Champions, and later to the NCAA championship tournament where they fell two games short of advancing to the College World Series. In 2012, the team recorded its best record ever and swept the ASC conference tournament to win the Conference title outright for a second consecutive year. Prior to Boggs' tenure, Mike Gardner was head coach since 1998. He retired at the end of the 2009 season as the winningest coach in school baseball history and led the team to its only appearance in the College World Series in 2002.{{Cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/2002_Division_III_College_World_Series|title=2002 Division III College World Series - BR Bullpen|website=www.baseball-reference.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-23}}{{cite web |url=http://athletics.concordia.edu/athletics.cfm?page_ID=44 |title=Concordia University Coaching Staff - Baseball |work=CTX.edu |accessdate=2008-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070812204831/http://athletics.concordia.edu/athletics.cfm?page_ID=44 |archivedate=2007-08-12 |df= }} Tornado field debuted on the new campus in February 2011 and was dedicated in April 2011. It is home to Tornado Baseball. === Other sports === Chris Randle became the first student athlete from Concordia to qualify for the NCAA track and field championship tournament. His {{convert|6|ft|7|in|cm|adj=on}} high jump earned him a sixth-place finish in the tournament. Randle's participation marked the first time in school history that Concordia was represented at the NCAA Division III Championships in two sports during the same academic year, as the baseball team won the ASC title and won two games over nationally ranked opponents – Linfield and Redlands – at the West Regional. In 2009 Concordia inducted its first ever Hall of Fame class, including the 2002 baseball team that played for the NCAA Division III College World Series and Atlanta Braves reliever [[Scott Linebrink]]. In 2011, three more members were inducted: Kenneth DeBord '02, basketball; Lisa Hintz '88, volleyball & basketball and Linda Lowery, who served stints as the Athletic Director, volleyball coach and men's and women's golf coach from 1980-2008. ==Alumni== * [[David R. Burns]], Maine politician * [[Scott Linebrink]], baseball player * Randy Phillips, musician, [[Phillips, Craig and Dean]] ==Photo gallery== File:Concordia University Texas Aerial.jpg|Aerial view of Concordia University's new campus in Northwest Austin. File:Concordiabell.jpg|Wendish bell that used to sit in front of the chapel on Concordia's former campus. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Portal|Austin|University}} *[http://www.concordia.edu Official website] *[http://athletics.concordia.edu Official athletics website] {{Concordia}} {{Private colleges and universities in Texas}} {{American Southwest Conference navbox}} {{Austin}} [[Category:Liberal arts colleges]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Austin, Texas]] [[Category:Universities and colleges affiliated with the Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]] [[Category:Universities and colleges accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1926]] [[Category:Concordia University Texas|*]] [[Category:Sorbian-American culture in Texas]] [[Category:1926 establishments in Texas]]

[[File:Design-Studies-Graph.jpg|thumb|This image describes the matrix of design studies. The inner circle describes the subject(s) of design, the outer, its context.]] '''Design Studies''' is an [[Discipline (academia)|academic discipline]] that pursues a critical understanding of [[design]] and its effects through analytical and practical modes of inquiry. Its origins can be traced to [[design history]] where the field first got its start<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Buchanan|first1=Richard|title=Design Research and the New Learning|journal=Design Issues|date=2001|volume=17,|issue=4|pages=3–23}}</ref> before slowly expanding to include larger themes and more varied subject matters. In that light, Victor Margolin, one of the founders of the discipline in the US, proposes Design Studies as a term that comprises various design researches and relates them to one another.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Margolin|first1=Victor|title=Design History or Design Studies: Subject Matter and Methods|journal=Design Issues|date=1995|volume=11|issue= 1|pages=4–15}}</ref>
As a highly interdisciplinary field, Design Studies references many scholarship paradigms and focuses on how design knowledge is developed, articulated and communicated.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cross|first1=Nigel|title=Design Research: A Disciplined Conversation|date=1999|volume=15|issue=02|pages=5}}</ref> It therefore incorporates an expansive set of evolving methodologies and theories that are drawn from key thinkers and theorists from the field itself (such as [[Victor Margolin]], Clive Dilnot, and [[Richard Buchanan (academic)|Richard Buchanan]]), but also from several related fields such as, the [[humanities]] ([[literature]], [[art]], [[Visual Studies|visual studies]], [[cultural studies]]), the [[social science]]s ([[anthropology]], [[political science]]s, and [[sociology]]), the [[science]]s ([[engineering]], [[Materials science|material]] studies, [[neurology]], [[technology]] studies). Design Studies also generates scholarly work in the fields of [[architecture]], [[urban planning]] and [[Urban policy|policy]], and spatial studies. Design Studies not only considers objects, places and systems, it investigates their meanings, contexts, possibilities and consequences.
Design Studies recognizes that design, as a practice, is merely one facet of a much larger paradigm. It examines, probes, and questions the role of design in shaping past and present personal and cultural values, especially in light of how they shape the future. The subjects of Design Studies are inherently fluid while being anchored to a core body of work and scholarship that revolves around broader themes such as [[ethics]], environmental sustainment, and [[social sustainability]].
The American author, editor and educator Susan Yelavich, encapsulates the terrain of Design Studies as embracing "two broad perspectives—one that focuses inward on the nature of design and one that looks outward to the circumstances that shape it, and conversely, the circumstances design changes, intentionally or not."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://adht.parsons.edu/designstudies/double_profile_of_design_studie/|title=The Double Profile of Design Studies - Design Studies|website=adht.parsons.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-20}}</ref>
Masters programs in Design Studies are offered in the United States at [[Carnegie Mellon School of Design]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://design.cmu.edu/content/design-studies|title=Design Studies {{!}} Carnegie Mellon School of Design|website=design.cmu.edu|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> [[Harvard Graduate School of Design]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gsd.harvard.edu/design-studies/|title=Master in Design Studies (MDes) - Harvard Graduate School of Design|website=www.gsd.harvard.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> [[Parsons School of Design]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newschool.edu/parsons/ma-design-studies-research/|title=Design Studies MA: Design Theory for Social Change {{!}} The New School|website=www.newschool.edu|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> and [[IIT Institute of Design]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.id.iit.edu/master-of-design/|title=Master of Design {{!}} IIT Institute of Design|website=www.id.iit.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref>
== History ==
=== History of Design Studies === The history of the field of Design Studies can be traced to the early 1960s in England. In 1962, a “Conference on Design Methods” held in London led to the emergence of the [[Design Research Society]], bringing together academics and practitioners who shared interests in new approaches to the process of designing.<ref name="Forty Years of Design Research">{{cite journal|last1=Cross|first1=Nigel|title=Forty Years of Design Research|journal=Design Studies|date=2007|volume=28|issue=1|pages=1–4}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=About|url=https://www.designresearchsociety.org/cpages/about|website=Design Research Society}}</ref> Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, a series of conferences were held that helped continue the development of the [http://www.drs2016.org/222/ Design Methods Movement (DMM)]— a product of the post-war optimism of the 1950s, cancelled in 1962.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cross, Margolin|first1=Nigel, Victor|title=A History of Design Methodology, Design Methodology and Relationships with Science|date=1993|publisher=Kluwer Academic Publishers|page=16}}</ref> This movement focused on the comparison between science and design and tried to determine methods that distinguished design as an important academic field apart from the realm of art and art history. However, in 1980 at the Design Research Society’s [https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/005784314 Design:Science:Method] conference concluded that there was not much for design to learn from science, instead, science had something to learn from design.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cross, Margolin|first1=Nigel, Victor|title=A History of Design Methodology, Design Methodology and Relationships with Science|date=1993|publisher=Kluwer Academic Publishers|page=19}}</ref> From this point, design became a discipline of study “based on the view that design has its own things to know and its own ways of knowing them.” This stance was promulgated in the first issue of ''[https://www.journals.elsevier.com/design-studies Design Studies]'' with the launch of a series of articles in its pages called “Design as a Discipline''.''”<ref name="Forty Years of Design Research"/> (''[https://www.journals.elsevier.com/design-studies Design Studies, The Interdisciplinary Journal of Design Research]'' as it is now known, was first published as Design Studies 1, no.1 in July 1979. Produced by the publisher Reed Elsevier known since 2015 as [[Elsevier]]). The series began with [[L. Bruce Archer|Bruce Archer]], and his 1979 essay, “Whatever became of Design Methodology?”.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Archer|first1=Bruce|title=Whatever Became of Design Methodology?|journal=Design Studies|date=1979|volume=1|issue=1|page=17}}</ref> In his accompanying article from the same issue titled "The Three Rs," Archer places [[Design]] with a capital D as a third extreme in an education triangle with the [[Science]]s and [[Humanities]] situating design, though not exclusively, within acts of configuration, composition, meaning, value, and purpose in man-made phenomena.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Archer|first1=Bruce|title=The Three Rs|journal=Design Studies|date=1979|volume=1|issue=1|pages=17–20}}</ref>
Debates about the discipline of design and design research continued through the 1980s and were significantly reignited in 1995 when [[Victor Margolin]], an American scholar who contributed to the development of design history, argued for a new approach to “Design Studies.”<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=Margolin|first1=Victor|title=Design History or Design Studies: Subject Matter and Methods|journal=Design Issues|date=1995|volume=11|issue= 1|page=14|doi=10.2307/1511610}}</ref> Margolin referred to the "dynamic crossings of intellectual boundaries" when describing the interdisciplinary nature of intellectual practice at the time. He felt that early design historians should question "whether design history as it [had] been constituted...[was] a viable enterprise."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Margolin|first1=Victor|title=Design History or Design Studies: Subject Matter and Methods|journal=v|date=1995|volume=11|issue= 1|pages=4–15|doi=10.2307/1511610}}</ref><ref>Gooding, J. V., “Design History in Britain From the 1970's to 2012: Context, Formation and Development, Ph.D. Dissertation University of Northumbria, Newcastle (January 2012) p. 200-203</ref>
Margolin defines design studies as a field of inquiry that addresses how we make and use products and how we have done so in the past. These products compromise the domain in the artificial. Design studies addresses ideas of product conception and planning, production, form, distribution, and use. It considers these topics in the present as well as in the past.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Margolin|first1=Victor|title=The Politics of the Artificial: essays on design and design studies|date=2002|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|page=229}}</ref>
Margolin's position triggered counter arguments about how to characterize the study of design. A battle in print began with his article titled, “Design history or design studies: subject matter and methods” published in the international journal ''Design Studies (Design Studies was the journal of the [[Design Research Society]], founded in the UK in 1966; the journal itself has been in publication since 1979).'' This controversial topic had resonance in Britain where [[Adrian Forty]]’s response appeared in the pages of the ''[[Journal of Design History]]'', in which he argued in favor of research that led to the understanding of quality judgements defining good design "as an entirely legitimate field for design historical research."<ref>{{cite journal|title=DEBATE: A Reply to Victor Margolin|journal=Journal of Design History|date=1 January 1993|volume= 6|issue= 2|pages=131–132}}</ref> The importance of this debate was made clear by the fact that it was reprinted in a special issue of ''[[Design Issues]]'' in 1995 where it refocused attention on "some of the controversies and problems that surround the seemingly simple task of telling the history of design."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Buchanan, Doordan & Margolin|first1=Richard, Dennis, Victor|title=Introduction|journal=v|date=Spring 1995|volume=11|issue= 1}}</ref> The shift from Design History to Design Studies started to occur as the research and approaches to the field began to focus on broader questions of meaning, authority and power, in other words, with the dynamics surrounding and enabling the practice of design.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Whiteley|first1=Nigel|title=Design History or Design Studies|date=1995|volume=1|issue= 1|pages=38–42|doi=10.2307/1511614}}</ref> The realization came that Design History is only “but one component of what goes on in studying design, and to claim that all that is going on now could use the umbrella term 'design history’ is not tenable.”<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Whiteley|first1=Nigel|title=Design History or Design Studies|date=1995|volume=1|issue= 1|page=40|doi=10.2307/1511614}}</ref> This new field of Design Studies would now include not only design history, but also allow for a dialogue about “issues of product conception and planning, production, form, distribution, and use” in a historical and contemporary context.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
=== Foundational Figures === [[L. Bruce Archer]]. (1922-2005) was a British mechanical engineer and later Professor of [[Design Research]] at the [[Royal College of Art]] who championed research in design, and helped to establish design as an academic discipline. Archer trained a generation of design researchers, showing them how the procedures of scholarly research based on well-founded evidence and systematic analysis were as applicable in design as in the more traditional academic subjects.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Archer|first1=Bruce|title=A View of the Nature of Design Research Design:Science:Method|date=1981|publisher=Westbury House|location=Guildford}}</ref> In 1967 he helped to found the cross-disciplinary [[Design Research Society]].<ref>Archer, Bruce, ‘A View of the Nature of Design Research’, in Jacques, R and Powell, J (eds), Design:Science:Method, Westbury House, Guildford, 1981</ref>
[[Reyner Banham]]. (1922-1988) Banham’s ''[https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/theory-and-design-first-machine-age Theory and Design in the First Machine Age]'' and his journalistic articles written for ''New Society'' have been described by the British writer and design historian [[Penny Sparke]] as representing a major “shift in how material culture was seen.<ref>Frith, S. (1995)Speaking Volumes: New Society (1962–87)THE 27 January 1995 Penny Sparke accredits Banham as a major influence on her own work, describing his work as “pivotal”. Sparke, P & DHS ( 2007) Oral History Project Interview with Penny Sparke; Track 1. From Gooding, J. V., Design History in Britain From the 1970' to 2012: Context, Formation and Development, Ph. D. Dissertation University of Northumbria, Newcastle (January 2012) p.  200-203</ref> His writing focused on popular commodities as well as formal architecture.
[[Gui Bonsiepe]]. (born 1934) German designer and professor for various universities including FH Koln; Carnegie Mellon; EUA, Chile; LBDI/FIESC, Brazil; Jan van Eyck Academy, Netherlands.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Brody, David Eric and Clark|first1=Hazel|title=Design studies: a reader|date=2009|publisher=Berg|location=Oxford}}</ref> His most influential work is ''Design and Democracy.''
[[Richard Buchanan (academic)|Richard Buchanan]]. American professor of design, management, and information systems and editor of the journal [[Design Issues]]. He is well known for “extending the application of design into new areas of theory and practice, writing, and teaching as well as practicing the concepts and methods of interaction design.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Faculty and Research|url=https://weatherhead.case.edu/faculty/Richard-Buchanan|website=weatherhead.case.edu}}</ref> As a co-editor of ''Discovering Design: Explorations in Design Studies'' with Victor Margolin, he brought together the fields of psychology, sociology, political theory, technology studies, rhetoric, and philosophy.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Margolin|first1=Victor|title=Discovering design explorations in design studies. Edited by Richard W. Buchanan|date=2010|publisher=Univ. of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0226078151}}</ref>
[[Buckminster Fuller|Richard Buckminster Fuller]]. [[Richard Coyne]]. Professor at the [[University of Edinburgh]] and author of several books on the implications of information technology and design particularly as developed by Coyne's colleague [[Adrian Snodgrass]] in the 1990s, and with whom he co-authored the book ''Interpretation in Architecture: Design as a Way of Thinking''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Richard Coyne|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Coyne}}</ref>
[[Nigel Cross]]. (born 1942) Cross is a British academic, design researcher and educator who focuses on design’s intellectual space in the academic sphere. He is a Professor of Design Studies in the Department of Design and Innovation, Faculty of Technology, at the UK's Open University, and Editor-in-Chief of Design Studies, the international journal of Design Research. With his 1982 journal article “Designerly Ways of Knowing” in ''Design Studies'', Cross argues that Design has its own intellectual and practical culture as a basis for education, contrasting it with cultures of Science and Arts and Humanities.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cross|first1=Nigel|title=Designerly ways of knowing|journal=Design Studies|volume=3|issue=4|pages=221–7|doi=10.1016/0142-694X(8290040-0}}</ref>
[https://www.moma.org/interactives/exhibitions/2013/designandviolence/author/cdilnot/ Clive Dilnot]. Originally educated as a fine artist, Dilnot later began studying social philosophy and the sociology of culture with Polish sociologist [[Zygmunt Bauman]]. Dilnot has worked on the history, theory, and criticism of the visual arts in their broadest terms. His teaching and writing have focused on design history, photography, [https://doi.org/10.1386/jwcp.1.2.177_1 criticism], and theory. Dilnot’s most significant contribution to design scholarship is a study of ethics in relation to design, and the role of design's capabilities in creating a humane world in his book, ''Ethics? Design?''<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/224949665|title=The archeworks papers|last=Dilnot|first=Clive|publisher=Archeworks|others=Tigerman, Stanley, 1930, Archeworks (Chicago, Ill.)|year=2004|isbn=0975340514|location=Chicago|pages=|oclc=224949665}}</ref> published in 2005. He has also written and taught in fields ranging from aesthetics and art theory to photography, the decorative arts, museums and their framing of objects, architecture and architectural theory, and the economics of the current crisis and the question of how we can contend culturally with the world we have made.<ref>{{cite web|title=The New School, Parsons, Faculty Profile|url=https://www.newschool.edu/parsons/faculty.aspx?id=4d54-6330-4f54-4578|website=newschool.edu|accessdate=November 13, 2017}}</ref>

Having worked closely with Tony Fry at the [http://www.changedesign.org/ Ecodesign Foundation] in the 1990s, Tonkinwise later headed initiatives in sustainability at Parsons, The New School, and later became chair of design studies at Carnegie Mellon University, where he set up the [https://design.cmu.edu/content/phd PhD programs] in [http://transitiondesign.net/ Transition Design] and Design Studies. Cameron's primary area of research is sustainable design and designing for socio-technical transitions - in particular, he focuses on the design of systems that lower societal materials intensity, primarily by decoupling use and ownership, i.e systems of shared use.
[[Adrian Forty]]: (born 1948) was Professor of Architectural History at The Bartlett, The Faculty of the Built Environment at University College London. Forty believed that the drive to define a new field, the field of Design Studies, was unnecessary due to the fact that the field of Design History had not exhausted all of its possibilities.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Forty|first1=Adrian|title=Debate: A Reply to Victor Margolin|journal=Design Issues|date=1995|volume=''11|issue= 1|pages=16–18|doi=10.2307/1511611}}</ref> His book ''Objects of Desire''<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/26320994|title=Objects of desire : design and society since 1750|last=Forty|first=Adrian,|date=1992|publisher=Thames and Hudson|year=|isbn=0500274126|location=New York, N.Y.|pages=|oclc=26320994}}</ref> explores how consumer goods relate to larger issues of social processes.<ref>{{cite book|title=Objects of desire : design and society since 1750|last1=Forty|first1=Adrian|date=1992|publisher=Thames and Hudson|year=|isbn=0500274126|location=New York, N.Y.|pages=}}</ref>
[[Tony Fry]] is a British design theorist and philosopher who writes on the relationship between design, [[unsustainability]], and politics. Fry has taught design and [[Culture theory|cultural theory]] in Britain, the United States, Hong Kong and Australia. He is perhaps best known for his writing as a defuturing<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/47009406|title=A new design philosophy : an introduction to defuturing|last=Tony.|first=Fry,|date=1999|publisher=UNSW Press|isbn=0868407534|location=Sydney|oclc=47009406}}</ref> phenomenon by virtue of the resources it depletes.
[[John Heskett]] (1937-2014) In the late 1970s, Heskett became a prominent member of a group of academics based in several of Britain's art schools (then part of the polytechnics) who helped develop the discipline of design history and theory, later to become subsumed under the broader banner of Design Studies. In subsequent years, as design became a global practice increasingly valued by corporations and governments alike, design history became, along with design pedagogy, one of the nation's most successful academic exports. Heskett brought his deep knowledge of economics, politics and history to the project and worked alongside scholars from other disciplines to communicate the meaning and function of that increasingly important concept, "design", both past and present.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sparke|first1=Penny|title=John Heskett obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/mar/12/john-heskett|website=the guardian|accessdate=October 31, 2017}}</ref>
[[Victor Margolin]] (DS-History) Considered one of the founders of Design Studies, Victor Margolin is Professor Emeritus of Design History at the University of Illinois, Chicago. [[Victor Papanek]]. === Development Outside Anglo-Saxon === According to Ahmed Ansari, Danah Abdulla, Ece Canli, Mahmoud Keshavarz, Matthew Kiem, Pedro Oliveira, Luiza Prado, and Tristan Schultz who make up the ''[http://www.decolonisingdesign.com/ Decolonising Design Group]'', “Coloniality is not an abstract concept nor is it a subject to be examined from a comfortable distance. It is something that affects our communities, our countries and our peoples every single day. It is a continuous process of domination and violence to which we are submitted. It demeans our knowledge, subjugates our bodies, and renders our lives arduous.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Decolonising Design, A Statement on the Design Research Society Conference 2016|url=http://www.decolonisingdesign.com/statements/2016/drs2016statement/#more-1|website=Decolonising Design|accessdate=November 12, 2017}}</ref>
Established via their online blog “[http://www.decolonisingdesign.com/ Decolonising Design],” this collective of design researchers, academics, and practitioners working in and with the fields of Design Studies and Design Research firmly believe that “decolonisation is imperative for survival.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Decolonising Design, A Statement on the Design Research Society Conference 2016|url=http://www.decolonisingdesign.com/statements/2016/drs2016statement/#more-1|website=Decolonising Design|accessdate=November 12, 2017}}</ref> The Decolonising Design Group's effort was born from their frustrations with academia during the events that led up to their withdrawal from the 2016 Design Research Society Conference and driven by their desire to engage in a profound debate of the colonial ethos of design and research. The collective believes it is, “not sufficient for design studies and design research to simply include a greater ‘diversity of perspectives’ as a means to delay and offset demands for radical systemic change.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Decolonising Design, A Statement on the Design Research Society Conference 2016|url=http://www.decolonisingdesign.com/statements/2016/drs2016statement/#more-1|website=Decolonising Design|accessdate=November 12, 2017}}</ref> With the purpose of transforming the agenda of design studies and design research, the group organized a symposium on decolonization titled “Intersectional Perspectives on Design, Politics & Power” which was held at the School of Arts and Communication, Malmö University, Sweden on 14–15 November 2016. For these [relatively] young academics, the field of design studies is not “geared towards delivering the kinds of knowledge and understanding that are adequate to addressing the systemic problems that arise from the coloniality of power.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Editorial Statement|url=http://www.decolonisingdesign.com/statements/2016/editorial/#more-1|website=Decolonising Design|accessdate=November 13, 2017}}</ref>
They argue that design history and design research tends to have the most influence from the triad of Western Europe, North America, and Japan.<ref name="Design studies: a reader">{{cite book|last1=Turner|first1=Matthew|title=Design studies: a reader|date=2009|publisher=Berg|location=Oxford:|pages=20–24}}</ref> The effect tends to be in line with the notion that history is written by the victors and thus design history is written by the economically powerful.<ref name="Design studies: a reader"/> They point to concurrent histories outside of the western context. For instance, Hong Kong has a unique system of design that was established prior to the economic growth of the Pearl River delta which can be found in the continuities of design in product types and styles, manufacturing and printing companies, and families of artist-designers.<ref name="Design studies: a reader"/> Or in Cuba for instance, where the origins of design was influenced by the crisis of “modern movement ideology and the ideologies oh how to escape underdevelopment.”<ref>{{cite book|title=Design studies: a reader|date=2009|publisher=Berg|location=Oxford|isbn=978-1847882363|pages=25–30}}</ref> These countries lie on the periphery of the westernized view of design history and design studies and in some instances may have suffered in their adaptation of European modernity. As such, [[Gui Bonsiepe]], a German designer, teacher, and writer, suggested that “Decolonization in all its manifestations, economic, technological and cultural, should be the goal of project activity in the periphery.”<ref>{{cite book|title=Design studies: a reader|date=2009|publisher=Berg|location=Oxford|isbn=978-1847882363|page=27}}</ref>
The need for understanding design as a global and multicultural phenomenon is also argued by Jonathan M. Woodham, [[Victor Margolin]], and Anna Calvera in Denise Whitehouse’s collection of essays.”<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite book|title=Design studies: a reader|date=2009|publisher=Berg|location=Oxford|isbn=978-1847882363|pages=54–63}}</ref> Together their aim is to “create a theoretical narrative that brings intellectual logic to the multiple stories of how different countries… have negotiated the process of Westernization and the idea of design according to their specific economic, geographical, political, and cultural circumstances.”<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
As Whitehouse points out, “While many countries produce local histories of design, the output is uneven and often driven by nationalist and trade agendas.”<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Academic groups like the Japanese [http://www.designhistoryforum.org/ Design History Forum] and [http://www.ub.edu/icdhs/ The International Committee for Design History and Studies (ICDHS)] draw together both western and non-western, post-communist, postcolonial, Asian, and Southern Hemisphere, “to remap the scope and narrative concerns of design history.”<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
